Padded.name: Padded
Padded.description: This armor is made of several layers or tough cloth stuffed with padding

Leather.name: Leather
Leather.description: This armor is made of toughed animal skin. It's great protection for someone that wants to stay fully mobile.

Studded leather.name: Studded leather
Studded leather.description: This leather armor has metal rivets attached to it in a pattern.

Chain shirt.name: Chain shirt
Chain shirt.description: A chain shirt comes with a steel cap.

Hide.name: Hide
Hide.description: This armor is made of animal skin, but usually still contains the thick fur. It's great for keeping the wearer warm and stopping weapons from finding purchase.

Scale mail.name: Scale mail
Scale mail.description: This armor is made of small scales of metal or animal. The suit includes gauntlets.

Chainmail.name: Chainmail
Chainmail.description: This armor is a long clock that is fashioned of rings and offers great protection from cuts. The suit includes gauntlets.

Breastplate.name: Breastplate
Breastplate.description: This armor is great for protecting the vital area of the body, but still allowing mobility. It comes with a helmet and greaves.

Splint mail.name: Splint mail
Splint mail.description: This armor is made of long strips of metal, or tough wood, that hand vertically. The suit includes gauntlets.

Banded mail.name: Banded mail
Banded mail.description: This armor is made of long strips of metal that encricle the wearer. The suit includes gauntlets.

Half-plate.name: Half-plate
Half-plate.description: This armor offers the most proctection for those that can't quite, or don't desire to, handle full plate. The suit includes gauntlets.

Full plate.name: Full plate
Full plate.description: The suit includes gauntlets, heavy leather boots, a visored helmet, and a thick layer of padding that is worn underneath the armor. Each suit of full plate must be individually fitted to its owner by a master armorsmith, although a captured suit can be resized to fit a new owner at a cost of 200 to 800 (2d4x100) gold pieces.

Buckler.name: Buckler
Buckler.description: This small metal shield is worn strapped to your forearm. You can use a bow or crossbow without penalty while carrying it. You can also use your shield arm to wield a weapon (whether you are using an off-hand weapon or using your off hand to help wield a two-handed weapon), but you take a -1 penalty on attack rolls while doing so. This penalty stacks with those that may apply for fighting with your off hand and for fighting with two weapons. In any case, if you use a weapon in your off hand, you dont get the bucklers AC bonus for the rest of the round.

Shield, light wooden.name: Shield, light wooden
Shield, light wooden.description: Wooden and steel shields offer the same basic protection, though they respond differently to special attacks

Shield, light steel.name: Shield, light steel
Shield, light steel.description: Wooden and steel shields offer the same basic protection, though they respond differently to special attacks

Shield, heavy wooden.name: Shield, heavy wooden
Shield, heavy wooden.description: Wooden and steel shields offer the same basic protection, though they respond differently to special attacks.

Shield, heavy steel.name: Shield, heavy steel
Shield, heavy steel.description: Wooden and steel shields offer the same basic protection, though they respond differently to special attacks.

Shield, tower.name: Shield, tower
Shield, tower.description: This massive wooden shield is nearly as tall as you are. In most situations, it provides the indicated shield bonus to your AC. However, you can instead use it as total cover, though you must give up your attacks to do so. The shield does not, however, provide cover against targeted spells; a spellcaster can cast a spell on you by targeting the shield you are holding. You cannot bash with a tower shield, nor can you use your shield hand for anything else.
